options.text: decreases when the elasticity of the aorta increases
decreases when the peripheral resistance increases
decreases when the stroke volume increases
decreases whenever the systolic pressure increases

questions.text: The decreased compliance of the elastic arteries results in

options.text: a decreased systolic pressure
a decreased diastolic pressure
an increased mean pressure
an increased pulse pressure

questions.text: When a person is standing, mean arterial pressure

options.text: at the level of the heart remains 100 mmHg
of the large artery in the brain is about 60 mmHg
of the large artery in the foot is about 190 mmHg
does not differ from the reclining position
is directly proportional to cardiac output and peripheral resistance
is approximately equal to the diastolic pressure plus one-third of the pulse pressure
decreases with age
in a large artery in the foot will change from about 100 mmHg to about 180 mmHg when a recumbent person stands up

questions.text: Increases in arterial pulse pressure may be caused by:

options.text: decreases in stroke volume
decreases in arterial blood volume
increases in heart rate
decreases in arterial compliance

questions.text: The pressure pulse in the systemic arteries

options.text: propagates at about 5 m/sec
is produced by the ejection of blood into the aorta
is palpable at the wrist shortly after ventricular ejection
has the same velocity as arterial blood flow

questions.text: The decreased compliance of the elastic arteries results in

options.text: a decreased systolic pressure
an increased mean pressure
a decreased diastolic pressure
an increased pulse pressure

options.text: a decreased diastolic pressure
a decreased systolic pressure
an increased pulse pressure
an increased mean pressure

questions.text: Which of the following statements are correct?

options.text: damping of the high frequency components of the pressure pulse is especially marked during transmission
the diastolic component of the pressure pulse decreases during transmission in the arterial system
arteriolar vasodilation may result in significant pulsations in the capillaries
propagation velocity of the pressure pulse is much higher than the velocity of the blood flow
the amplitude of the pressure pulse is very dependent on the compliance of the arteries
the amplitude of systolic component of the pressure pulse increases during transmission in the arterial system
may result from an increased sympathetic activity
results in a larger increase in the systolic pressure than in the diastolic
results in an increase of the pulse pressure
promotes venous return
does not influence the pulse pressure significantly
